PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer him to the statement of Mrs Kelly that the tape of her meeting with environmental leaders will not be produced by today's deadline in accordance with the order of the Senate. I ask: does this mean that it is Mrs Kelly who decides whether or not orders of the Senate directed to the Government are complied with?

—As I understand it, this is a matter of constitutional practice concerning the powers and privileges of the Senate and the House of Representatives. It is ultimately a matter to be resolved between the two Houses, if necessary. In so far as Mrs Kelly's claim is concerned, I think that she is entitled to make that position clear. In so far as the Senate is concerned, it is all very well for Senator Hill to describe it as an order of the Senate, but it is a resolution of the Senate, and that can be resolved only between the two Houses.

—I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister saying that this is a decision for Mrs Kelly and not a decision for the Government, notwithstanding that the resolution or order-whichever word one chooses to use-is directed to the Government and not Mrs Kelly?
—I do not think that I can add anything to what the Prime Minister said yesterday about that.
— Does the Minister for Industrial Relations have information on the rate of accidents and injuries on Australian farms? What action has been taken to remedy the record of fatalities on farms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is acutely aware of the alarming rate of injuries in rural Australia. In 1989, Worksafe Australia reported on workplace fatalities and stated that the farming sector had the third highest number of deaths at work after the mining and transport industries. In fact, the average annual fatality in farming Australia is at the ratio of 19.4 per 100,000 compared to the all industry average in Australia of 8.1 per 100,000. Over the two years of the Worksafe study, 257 farm related fatalities, including 34 involving children under the age of 15, were identified. The major cause of death was mobile mechanical equipment, which accounted for 70 per cent of the deaths. About 40 per cent of all farm related deaths were caused by tractors or equipment attached to tractors.

ANSWER.PARA: To help farming communities improve rural occupational health and safety, Worksafe Australia has developed, in association with farming organisations, a safety kit called the State farm safety kit. I have one of those kits here, and I will just show it to the Senate and make it available for honourable senators who wish to have access to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hold it up a bit.

—I will hold up the farm safety kit. It is a substantial piece of work by Worksafe Australia. There are now 25 different rural communities which have formed farm safety committees in their region and which use this kit and there are some five others that are being established. This is a major improvement in lifting the standard of safety in rural Australia, and I commend Worksafe for the work it is doing on it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister indicate whether the Prime Minister or any of his Ministers have listened to and heard the tape that records the meeting between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the leading conservationists?

—I said earlier, as the Prime Minister told the House of Representatives yesterday, he informed the Leader of the Opposition that a member of his staff did not ask for the tape but saw a copy of the relevant part of the transcript, read the relevant part of the transcript and informed the Prime Minister that the transcript totally endorsed and confirmed what the Minister had told him. I have nothing to add to that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the circumstances, does the Minister not find it quite extraordinary that no Minister has taken the trouble to listen to that tape so as to be able to comment upon it? The matter has become one of major public importance.
—I do not find it extraordinary at all.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services share the concern of students about the severity of the crisis in higher education regarding overcrowding and underfunding, including the open flouting of health and safety regulations with students crammed into aisles, sitting on the floor, on rubbish tins or on milk crates and standing at the back of lecture theatres? Does the Minister endorse the practice of the issuing of tickets to lectures, students being locked out of lectures, more lectures being held after hours and in off-campus venues, and tutorials which are almost as large as lectures? Is the Minister aware of severe shortages of library books, computer terminals and other resources, modifications to curriculum and assessment processes, and the abolition of many tutorials? Will the Minister make a commitment to restore funding to at least 1983 levels per full time student and provide additional funding for a 3.5 per cent annual growth in the number of higher education places in the next 10 years, as requested by the Higher Education Round Table which nationally represents students, postgraduates and academics?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one thing, amongst others, that I have learnt in answering questions from Senator Bell.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Collins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only one, but one amongst a number. One of the main things is that I do not take at face value the assertions that Senator Bell makes. I have had a number of instances in other areas of education policy where assertions have been made and they have not withstood scrutiny. In not responding to some of the specific assertions made by Senator Bell, I will address the issue of overcrowding or over-enrolments-because there is a difference-and I will also go to the impact of the most recent Budget on higher education.
—Why don't you just answer the question he asked?

—If Senator Macdonald was listening-and it probably is a bit early for him-he would realise that the underlying premise of Senator Bell's questions goes to over-enrolments and overcrowding and what the Government is doing. I will not go to the specific instances of libraries and whatever but I will go to the core issue, and that is answering the question.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of over-enrolments, we recognise and we are addressing this problem. We recognise that a number of factors have contributed to over-enrolment. But the Government's view is that over-enrolment appears to be occurring principally because of increased retention rates of students and increased acceptance of offers by applicants for new places. Both of these have exceeded the projections of institutions based on previous experience.

A number of reasons have contributed to the change in retention acceptance rates, including the current economic recession and increased school retention rates. While it is difficult to control the retention rates of continuing students, institutions do have more control on the number of new students. The number of offers made to new students must be more closely monitored and adjusted to particular circumstances.

It is worth noting that a recent report by the Victorian Post-Secondary Education Commission suggested that almost half of the over-enrolment problems in Victoria are due to existing students staying on at universities in that context. Mr Baldwin's Department and the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee are undertaking a joint analysis of the statistics and profile returns of institutions with a view to coming to agreement on a broad system-wide approach to the problem. Following these discussions, and prior to the forthcoming profile discussions with higher education institutions, Mr Baldwin will be making a statement on an agreed strategic approach to this problem.

To the extent that the Government recognises the problem and also reflecting our continued commitment to the expansion of higher education opportunities, Senator Bell should recognise that in this financial year we have provided an extra $76m, and $42m for 1993. The bulk of this will be used to help alleviate the pressure of over-enrolments and overcrowding. That is an important part of the Budget and one which should be recognised for the important measure it is, in terms of combating the over-enrolment problem.

Enrolment growth assistance will total $70m over the next four years. This will be built into the base operating grants for institutions. That is an important contribution. In 1992, $9m will also be provided for assistance with enrolment growth and $53m for new buildings and refurbishment. The extra $53m for refurbishments and acceleration of new building projects brings total capital funding for 1992 to $266m, which compares with $213m this financial year. On a rough calculation that is at least 20 per cent extra over this financial year.

In addition, if Senator Bell were to be even-handed about this, he would take into account that the Government has taken steps towards increasing the contribution by industries to higher education and at the same time providing extra growth. Up to 600 new places in 1992, and 700 in both 1993 and 1994, will be funded on a cost-sharing basis with employers. Senator Bell has raised a number of assertions, probably all with an eye to grabbing the odd headline here or there.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is ungracious-absolutely ungracious.

—Senator Boswell knows that it is also true. Basically, the Government has recognised a need for action in this area. We have responded not only by way of assistance in terms of catering for enrolment growth-the extra $70m over the next four years is important there-but also by recognising the need for capital expenditure in institutions as well.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know whether the Minister was trying to deny the existence of the symptoms of overcrowding that I described or whether he is just expressing his insensitivity for what the National Union of Students has observed. I ask the Minister: are these promises for the future in recognition of the success of the Government's strategy and policies in higher education? If they are, why was the success of these policies not predicted so that we would not be in this mess now because it would have been catered for already?

—That is a petty, carping supplementary question. To make the assertion that the Government does not recognise or I am insensitive to the problems in this sector has no substance in fact. Senator Bell refers to promises into the future. The Budget is before this Parliament. It is being assessed by this Parliament. In that Budget one finds that allocation of moneys. If that is the best Senator Bell can do he is letting his constituency down enormously. The money is in the Budget and it will be spent. That is the best form of commitment any party in this place can give. It is very easy for him to sit over there making all sorts of offers in terms of his constituency but he must acknowledge that the money is in the Budget. It is not a promise for the future; it is happening now.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs and regards privacy protection for all Australians. What further steps has the Government recently taken to ensure that Australians have access to credit information records held about them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to inform the Senate that from 24 September Australians will be able to have access to their credit records: information held in relation to those transactions between credit providers and borrowers which is so much a part of the ordinary life of every Australian, as we do live in a debt-ridden society.

ANSWER.PARA: Any Australian who is a borrower will be able to have access, free of charge, to any credit information held on that person by a credit reporting agency. Basically this would be the Credit Reference Association of Australia Ltd or the Tasmanian Collection Service. People will be able to get hold of this credit record, free of charge, every six months. I believe that is a very important access entitlement of borrowers to credit records which are held about them. Not only that, but they will be able to check on those records as to their accuracy and the timeliness of the information held. If they are found to be inaccurate, the Credit Reference Association or the Tasmanian Collection Service will have to inform all those who have been notified of the inaccurate information recorded during the previous three months.

This is being done under an arrangement worked out by Kevin O'Connor, the Privacy Commissioner, in consultation with the Credit Reference Association. I believe this is a very useful exercise of his powers to hold consultations and to devise a code of conduct in relation to privacy which will well serve the interests of all Australians. I certainly urge all those who are borrowers in our community to take advantage of these rights, as I say, from 24 September.

In relation to the some other elements of the privacy legislation, it is necessary to postpone their coming into effect until 25 February next year to enable financial institutions and credit reporting agencies to put into place necessary computer systems and other technology. Those regulations will also come into place and that will be an important completion of the regime of privacy that will be put in place in relation to the credit reports which are held on, I guess, almost every Australian in our society.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the recent strength of the Australian dollar, both before and since last week's interest rate cut. Does the Minister agree with the reports from financial markets that this strength is due to the fact that real interest rates in Australia are amongst the highest in the world? Particularly in light of expectations of a fall in official US interest rates which will make Australia's real interest rates relatively even more attractive to overseas investors and thereby put further upward pressure on the Australian dollar, I ask the Minister: what action do the Government and the Reserve Bank of Australia propose to take to prevent the Australian dollar rising to a level that adversely affects Australian exporters even more?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short ought to know better than what he said in the second part of the question. If the Government proposed-and indeed it does not-to take any action about a dollar which is floating--
—Floating! You have had a massive intervention in the past 24 hours.

—Senator Crichton-Browne knows what I mean. If the Government proposed any action, one certainly would not announce it during Question Time in the Senate. Senator Short ought to know better than to ask a question such as that.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not want to speculate about the behaviour of the Australian dollar. It has been an issue which has confounded economists and commentators, particularly at the time of the Gulf war, for example. It is probably still doing so. I do not want to offer speculative views about the way in which the dollar is behaving or is likely to behave.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask the Minister, who is being unduly sensitive on that issue, a supplementary question. I know he has had some problems in recent days. It does not absolve him in this instance, though. Does the Minister not agree that a more responsible approach by the Government to fiscal and associated policies would have prevented this unwelcome upward pressure on the Australian dollar occurring in the first place?
—I do not understand Senator Short's definition of more responsible fiscal policy.
—Of course you don't.
—No, I do not.
—But your policies have thrown one million people out of work.

—Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition could be quiet for a minute. He is talking about people being thrown out of work. He ought to understand that the suggested fiscal policy announced by Senator Short in the Senate prior to the Budget and by his Leader subsequent to the Budget would have had the Budget in balance, something the Opposition never did in its entire time in government. It would have had thousands more people out of work as a result of that fiscal policy. If that is what Senator Short wants, he should go out there in the stumps and say it. He comes in here talking about more responsible fiscal policy, which is an entirely subjective view. I do not regard his view of the matter as responsible and I do not attempt to define what that means.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to a number of reports from NGO workers and United Nations agency staff currently involved with humanitarian relief work in Iraq. On the basis that all these reports point to widespread human suffering amongst civilians in Iraq-with a breakdown in health care, power supplies, food production and distribution, water supplies and quality, and the prediction of substantially greater famine and far greater pressure on a deteriorating health system by the end of the year-I ask the Minister whether the Australian Government is now prepared to argue at the United Nations that Iraq be allowed to purchase food and medicine out of its oil revenue before paying reparations, given that the country's minimum requirement this year for outside food and medicine is $3.5 billion and that the UN agencies, the Red Cross and NGOs can raise only about $200m. I accept that such distribution will need to be strictly controlled to prevent supplies going to the military, but I ask this question knowing that if the UN Security Council does not change its position an appalling tragedy will affect the people of Iraq within the next few months.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government obviously shares Senator Vallentine's concerns for the welfare of the people of Iraq, whatever our view may continue to be about the quality and character of its Government. We are aware of reports by UN officials and non-government organisations that warn of the possibility of a major human tragedy if humanitarian needs in Iraq are not addressed swiftly.

ANSWER.PARA: The 28 August report of Prince Sadruvdin Aga Khan, the Secretary-General's delegate on humanitarian needs in Iraq, estimates the cost of imports required to maintain normal food consumption levels to be $US1.32 billion for a six-month period. Security Council resolution No. 706 of 15 August permits the sale by Iraq of up to $US1.6 billion worth of oil over a six-month period, subject to the payment by Iraq of 30 per cent of this amount into the compensation fund and lesser amounts to pay for ongoing UN activities in Iraq. Iraq will have $US933m available for its own purchasing after meeting these obligations.

In addition, there is already an ongoing UN and NGO humanitarian program in Iraq, which is providing food, medicine and health care to Iraqi civilians. Funding for this operation was provided by the international community through contributions to the UN humanitarian fund for civilians in the area. The UN is well aware of the need for early preparations for the harsh winter and, I am advised, is attempting to make appropriate arrangements.

As to the latter part of Senator Vallentine's question, the UN sanctions committee is empowered to review the level of sanctions applied to Iraq every 60 days in the light of the policies and practices of the Government of Iraq and may reduce or lift sanctions as it sees fit. Clearly, the behaviour of the Iraqi Government, in attempting to hide details of its nuclear and biological weapons programs, works against the possibility of sanctions being lifted entirely. Iraq does, however, retain the right to make purchases of food and other essential items from its own resources. Australia's sale of wheat to Iraq in June, for example, was paid for from Iraqi assets held in a Swiss bank account. The Government is generally mindful of the concerns that have been raised by Senator Vallentine and will certainly be continuing to watch the situation very closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Last Thursday with regard to Robe River, and in particular Cape Lambert Services and Westug, the Minister said that `it goes into voluntary liquidation and another company is contrived to take its place'. Then on Monday the Minister described Westug as a new company sponsored by Robe River. Is it not the fact that there is no relationship between Westug and Robe River? Did not Robe River decide to put its tug services out to tender, a tender which was won by an unrelated company Westug? If that is so, why did the Minister contrive a situation to damage one of Australia's most successful enterprises? Is the Minister simply a puppet of the Seamen's Union of Australia, or is there another explanation for the Minister's misleading the Senate in this way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—You did not check the veracity of the information, did you? You just accepted the brief.
—You didn't do your homework.
—Order! Ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will ignore them. It seems that Senator Crane has a brief from Robe River to pursue this question in some detail. Yesterday Senator Crane accused me of misleading the Parliament.
—You did.
—It is in the record.

—I did not mislead the Parliament. I resent that remark and ask for it to be withdrawn. I think that it is a reprehensible reflection on a member of this chamber. I resent it deeply. I did not mislead this chamber. For members opposite to throw an accusation around like that willy-nilly reflects very badly on them. In fact, Senator Crane misled this chamber yesterday when he accused me in an answer of misleading it and when he produced so-called statistics that the eight appeals that I had referred to had not been appeals by Robe River. Yesterday Senator Crane said, `I emphasise eight appeals by Robe River to the Industrial Relations Commission and two appeals to the High Court'. He went on to argue that that was not true.

ANSWER.PARA: I have the details of the eight appeals here. They start from 13 June 1989-an appeal by Robe River against a Commission decision, dismissed. There was another on 6 September, dismissed; another on 5 October, dismissed; another on 8= October, dismissed; another again on 8= October 1990, dismissed; another on 19= June 1991, substantially dismissed and part of it referred for another hearing; another on 19 June, and the same result for that; and another on 22 July. If anyone has misled this chamber, it has not been me; it has been Senator Crane in the case of this question. So far as Westug is concerned, I believe that a contrived arrangement has been arrived at by Robe River.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the evidence?

—I believe that on the basis that the wholly-owned subsidiary of Robe River, Cape Lambert Services, underwent a dispute with the Seamen's Union. In this context I should qualify the definition of `dispute'. This was not a strike or a stoppage but a paper dispute conducted through the Commission and exhausted through the Commission with appeals to the High Court.

ANSWER.PARA: After that matter came to a conclusion, this company went into voluntary liquidation-and lo and behold, out of the blue comes this company, which I understand a former captain of one of the tugs of Robe River formed. In those circumstances, I believe that this was a contrived arrangement. I think those opposite would be naive to pretend that in a robust industrial situation like this it was not. If they were, they would be arguing the cause of an employer wanting to avoid its legal requirements. I do not alter, I do not resile and I will not back down from any of the statements that I have made in this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations to also name the two cases he referred to in which the union appealed against Robe River.
—I said last week that there were eight appeals by Robe River to the Full Bench of the Commission and substantially the union was upheld in every single one of them. That is a matter of fact.
—The High Court matters have not been finished.
—If I were Senator Hill, I would not make that gesture in this chamber; it is a very offensive gesture.
—The High Court matters have not yet been finished.
—There were two other appeals by the union, that is true, but it does not deviate from the point: so what?

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to media reports that the ACTU congress has called for tighter gun controls? How will this expression of support from a major national institution assist in the desirable movement towards a nationwide approach to the possession of firearms in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard calls from the ACTU congress meeting yesterday on Federal and State governments to demand registration of all firearms, tighten eligibility rules governing the issue of shooters licences, and ban semi-automatic weapons. I am quite confident that in that resolution the congress is reflecting the views of its very wide membership in the Australian community and, of course, a much wider group of Australians, such as are reflected in the one million signatures gathered by the Sydney Telegraph Mirror in its petition calling for stricter gun control laws in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, when he said that workers and their families were often the unnecessary victims of lousy gun control legislation. I believe that once again he is well reflecting the concern of unions such as the police associations around Australia which have taken a very strong stance in this regard and have been joined by their New Zealand colleagues only this week at a meeting of the various associations in New Zealand. He is also reflecting the concern of the bank employees representatives, many of whom have had members killed, certainly injured and definitely threatened, intimidated and traumatised by the experience of being confronted by a bank robber wielding a weapon.

In so far as the congress called on Federal and State governments to once and for all resolve this issue decisively, we will take up that challenge at the Police Ministers Council meeting and then at the Premiers Conference. That focus will be not only in regard to gun control legislation, which must not be frustrated by the demarcations relating to old colonial boundaries-we must have a nationwide approach-but also it must be wedded to a much larger change in our society to do away with the culture of violence which underpins and underlies the occasional eruption into the type of massacre we saw at Strathfield Plaza and on other occasions.

The ACTU congress has added its voice to many other voices in the community, both of individuals and of organisations, which demand change by politicians in this regard. We will respond to that request from the community and I believe that, by the end of this year, we will have very fruitful social change Australia-wide in this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. It refers to the announcement of quotas imposed on Australian beef entering America. Does the Minister agree that a quota is the ultimate form of tariff and is completely contrary to the principles of GATT? The EC and the United States have increased their export subsidies while Australia has done everything to promote world trade by reducing tariffs, deregulating the wheat industry, lowering our quarantine standards, accepting a lower Codex import standard of food, and lifting the embargo on the sugar industry. As Senator Button was one of the prime architects of internationalising our trade, would he accept that the Australian trade position is so serious that it has reached a state of emergency? Would he use his position, as the third highest person in the Government, to urge the Prime Minister to lead a trade delegation, at a head of state level, directly to Mr Bush and other world leaders to represent Australia's position in this trade debate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard this morning that Mr Austen, the Chairman of the Meat and Livestock Corporation, is going to the United States I think today to carry out negotiations with the United States industry. I also heard a representative of the US beef growers being very sanguine, as it were, about the likely success of Mr Austen's mission.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Boswell has asked me to agree to a number of propositions which are of a general kind; for example, whether I regard quotas as a most pernicious form of trade protection. The answer to that is probably yes, although maybe some countries have devised a worse form of trade protection than that, but I am not aware of one.

As I understand it, the request of the United States Government is that our beef exporters would enter into voluntary restraint agreements. They were obliged to do that in 1982, 1983, 1987 and 1988. The so-called voluntary restraints are an art form developed particularly by the United States in its trading relationships with Japan. Whether they are accurately described as quotas, I do not know.

The point about Senator Boswell's question is that one does regard this form of trade negotiation as inconsistent with the United States general position in the Uruguay Round. It is certainly inconsistent with the interests of Australia. In that context, I am not sure what can be done apart from the action which the Government and the Meat and Livestock Corporation have taken.

It is not easy to ask the Prime Minister to go to the United States in respect of one particular industry, important as it is, on a mission which may or may not be successful. I very much doubt whether it would be successful. I do not think that is a matter which the Prime Minister has considered at this time.

The Government is doing all it can to obtain higher access, for our beef producers in various countries, to ensure that we are equitably treated as the major meat exporter with approximately 60 per cent of the market. Again, it serves to highlight the importance which has to be attached to a satisfactory outcome of the Uruguay Round. I cannot give Senator Boswell a more specific answer than that at this time. I just urge the support of the National Party in endeavours which the Government does make.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. What action is being taken to detect substandard ships trading in Australian waters? In particular what action is being taken against owners of the merchant ship recently reported in Townsville as being in a dangerous state of disrepair? Will the owners also be investigated for an alleged oil spill which is currently polluting local beaches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 August, a foreign flag vessel, the Moksong, was detected in Townsville by the master of a tug as having some serious structural damage above its waterline. The Moksong had gone to Townsville to load sugar. As a result of the report by the tug master to safety authorities, a marine inspector from the register of the ship, that is, the Korean register, inspected the ship and found that the damage was of such a nature that the ship would be endangered if it had been loaded with sugar. The ship was cleared to sail under light conditions and therefore was ordered to return to its home port for repairs without having been able to load its cargo.

ANSWER.PARA: The situation currently is that we carry out inspections of about 25 per cent of the vessels that enter Australian ports under our port inspection program in accordance with the international conventions that we are party to. This is a very high percentage in comparison with world practice. Regrettably, in the last year, 60 per cent of the ships that have been inspected have had to be detained because of serious structural problems or, unfortunately in the case of half of those vessels, serious deficiencies in the life saving equipment on board the ships. Under those circumstances, the ships are required to have repairs carried out in Australia before they are allowed to leave port. Following the Kirki incident, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is currently investigating practical means of upgrading, within the conventions that we are party to, the level of inspections on board these ships to make them more stringent and perhaps have a two stage system which involves being able to physically inspect certain designated areas of the ship as well as carrying out a paper inspection, which is the normal practice at this point in time.

There have been some oil spills in Queensland. It is not known at this stage whether this vessel was responsible. The spills occurred under our national plan in the area designated for Queensland jurisdiction. An investigation is currently being carried out by Queensland State authorities into spills which appear to be of ship bunker fuel, that is, fuel oil.

I know that samples have been taken and that at this point in time the investigation has ruled out two ships. The investigation is continuing. I am assured that, if the Queensland State authorities actually manage by chemical analysis to identify the ship from which the oil has come, prosecutions will be launched.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Why has the Department of Administrative Services failed to allow all fire protection maintenance service contractors who have been recognised by the Standards Association of Australia to tender for the provision of fire protection maintenance services to Commonwealth owned buildings in the ACT? Is the Minister aware that, of the five companies selectively chosen by him to provide these services, four are subsidiaries of the one major company? Is the Minister also aware that this closed shop tendering process is likely to cost the Australian taxpayers an estimated $5m over the life of the contract? Why is the Minister prepared to deny market forces the opportunity to determine the successful tenderer for the provision of fire maintenance services in Canberra?

—Senator Calvert raises a question about which I will get more detail. What I will say at this time is that things have not been what they should have been and are not what they always seem to be. A number of his colleagues have come in here making all sorts of assertions. The only advice I give Senator Calvert at this stage is: do not make their mistake by putting out press statements alleging all sorts of rorts and other misadventures and misdeeds when the truth may in fact be totally different from what he is asserting, as has been the experience of his colleagues.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the extent of the drug trade across the Burmese borders, particularly with China and Thailand? What is the estimated amount of heroin originating in Burma and any other Burmese narcotics which end up in the illegal drug trade in Australia? What steps is Australia taking to eliminate the trade in illegal narcotics between Australia and Burma?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the illegal and clandestine nature of opium and heroin production, it is obviously not possible to quantify precisely the extent of drug trafficking across Burmese borders. Opium and heroin produced in Burma are trafficked principally via Thailand, China and India. Thailand remains the primary trafficking route for narcotics produced in Burma. However, China's southern provinces of Yunnan, Guizhou and Guangxi have recently become major trafficking routes for heroin produced in Burma. By November 1990, Chinese authorities had intercepted over 1,000 kilograms of heroin.

ANSWER.PARA: Estimates for the 1990 production of opium in Burma vary considerably but can reasonably be placed in the range of 2,000 tonnes to 2,500 tonnes, with estimates for 1991 production in the same range. The best estimate is that there are 900 tonnes to 1,000 tonnes of opium available in Burma for processing to morphine and heroin, with almost all of this refined product being exported. The amounts that we are talking about-even though we cannot estimate them precisely-are horrifyingly large.

It is estimated that 70 per cent to 75 per cent of the heroin entering Australia is produced in the Golden Triangle, with the majority originating from Burma. Burma is not regarded as a source of illicit drugs other than opium and its derivatives. To control the illicit traffic in narcotics from the Golden Triangle, Australia is active in several areas. Narcotics related assistance is provided to South East Asia; the Australian Federal Police has liaison officers in Bangkok, Chiang Mai, Kuala Lumpur, Singapore, Manila and Hong Kong; and the Australian Customs Service again has extensive control operations at the customs barrier.

Recently, agreement has been reached on projects under the United Nations international drug control program subregional strategy for South East Asia. The first will be a joint drug abuse control project on the China-Burma border. Similarly, there is agreement, in principle, for a joint UNDCP-Burma-Thailand project. We may give consideration in the future to support for the UNDCP's joint projects with Burma.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this question on superannuation. The question does not contain a recognition that the 3 per cent award based superannuation that now applies in Australia arose out of wages forgone at the time it was introduced.
—Not so at all; you have not read the national wage case.
—Order! Let the Minister answer the question.

—As a result of the national wage case, wages were forgone and the amount was taken as superannuation, thus establishing in Australia an award entitlement for blue-collar workers who hitherto had not had a superannuation entitlement. It at least extended the right of superannuation more equitably than it was before.

ANSWER.PARA: Previously, managerial elites and white- collar workers were the recipients of superannuation. Now, as a consequence of the accord, blue-collar workers are too. The equity principle is being more extensively met. Senator Alston's question is about legislative superannuation that was announced in the Budget and how this Government intends to meet the criteria of equity to guarantee that all employees in this country have a superannuation entitlement.

There is an economic and social imperative that a form of national income retirement scheme be established now. We are all aware that the ageing of the Australian population is increasing and that by the end of the century there will be more people on the age pension per ratio of people in the work force than there are now. There will be fewer taxpayers supporting a higher pension pay-out. This requires a government to face those circumstances and make a decision about a national retirement scheme.
This Government has the courage to do that-it made such an announcement in the Budget. While this need is not recognised on the Opposition side, nonetheless it is recognised widely in the community.

Senator Alston asked whether or not the increase in superannuation entitlements will be an unfair impost on companies. The Treasurer announced that the superannuation legislation should apply from 1 July next year. So during the early phases of the economic recovery in the course of the next 12 months, there will be no additional superannuation impost.

The second point is that the superannuation impost has a line drawn under it. For those companies with a payroll of half a million dollars or less-typically companies in this country that employ about 24 people-there will be no increase in superannuation above the current award level of 3 per cent. So only medium and larger companies will meet the impost.

The third point, which I think answers Senator Alston's question-and I think I noted all aspects of it-is that the Government has worked out with the ACTU an arrangement that the level of superannuation contribution is to be regarded, in terms of future wage movements, as a way of ensuring that there is no wage break-out and is to be taken into consideration in terms of future aggregate wage outcomes. In short, that is to say that wages and superannuation are to be seen as a total cost and that the benefit can be taken in wages or superannuation in later systems.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
1. I can confirm that the Thai Government does impose a ban on the import of rice.

2. As part of the Uruguay Round Agriculture Negotiations outcome, Australia is seeking the conversion of all existing non-tariff barriers on agricultural products to tariffs. The Cairns group, of which both Thailand and Australia are members, believes that this fundamental reinstrumentation of existing barriers to more transparent forms of border protection, with subsequent reductions in these tariffs, will be an important element of a liberalising agriculture reform package. If the Cairns group's objectives in the negotiations are met, non-tariff barriers of this kind will be removed.

3. While our understanding from industry representatives is that Thailand is not an identified target for the export of Australian rice, one company has raised with us a specific aspect of Thailand's ban on the import of rice as it affects their product. We have been pursuing this case through our embassy in Bangkok and it will be taken up at the annual joint trade committee meeting which is due to be held in Melbourne from 17 to 18 September.

4. As part of widespread consultations on market access issues, we have just completed discussions in Bangkok with the Thai authorities aimed at reinforcing coordination on international trade negotiations and obtaining improvements in Thailand's tariff regime.

5. No useful purpose would be served by introducing Australian tariffs on imported rice. Our aim is to achieve with Thailand a balanced package of concessions that address each country's specific areas of trade interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Federal Government to more widely exercise its constitutional powers so as to more effectively and comprehensively protect the Australian environment.

Mr President, I had earlier accepted that arrangement in relation to time. As everybody knows, this issue has arisen in recent days as a consequence of meetings between the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, and representatives of various peak conservation groups around this country. I think that it is worth stressing and putting on the record the very wide constitutional powers which the Federal Government does possess in protecting the environment. On several occasions, we have seen both the Opposition, when it was in government, and the present Hawke Government exercise those powers.

What is of concern now is that there are substantial indications from media reports, from meetings between Minister Kelly and peak environment groups and from some of the documentation in relation to negotiations now proceeding between the Federal Government and the States that the Federal Government is seeking to apply those powers which it possesses much less assiduously than it has applied them in the past and very much to the detriment of the Australian environment. That is at a time when quite clearly many national issues are evident which can only be addressed at the national level, which therefore must necessarily involve the application of these constitutional powers and at a time when the Australian public, by all the polls which have been conducted, is indicating that it wants the Federal Government to exercise those powers because it recognises that, in many respects, the Australian environment is very much under threat.

The Federal Government has constitutional powers under section 51 of the Constitution. I remind the Senate that under section 51(i) the Federal Government can make laws for the good government of the Commonwealth with respect to trade and commerce with other countries and among the States-these are very wide powers indeed. Under section 51(xx) it can control the operations of foreign corporations and trading and financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth. Of course, the external affairs powers have been more widely used than those powers.

I think most people who dwell upon the meaning of those words would recognise that most, but not all, of the environmental damage occurring in Australia would relate to the operation of trading companies and corporations. Some damage would occur as a result of individual actions but most of it could be controlled by the Commonwealth using those powers. As I have indicated, we recognise that there are a number of areas where the States alone are incapable of properly exercising environmental management. National issues must be controlled at the national level. I will just mention a few of those areas.

In relation to national energy policy, the Federal Government has notionally-and I stress `notionally'-committed itself to the Toronto targets, which include reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005. Yet we have seen nothing at all from the Federal Government on exactly how it will make those targets stick. The State parliaments of Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and Victoria are entertaining schemes for the further development of power stations between now and the year 2005. We have seen nothing at all in relation to a national transport policy despite the fact that transport is one of the major users of fossil fuels and therefore a major emitter of greenhouse gases. We have seen nothing from the Federal Government which, at the national level, seriously addresses those problems.

It is clear that we need national standards on the quality of air and water. Just the other evening during a meeting of Estimates Committee A, officers and the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), who is at the table, spoke about the establishment of an EPA and the need to ensure that the standards which are likely to be set will take into account the lowest common denominator standards which can be agreed between the States.

Quite clearly, we need national standards in respect of the handling and disposal of toxic waste. Quite clearly, we need national legislation and national standards in respect of coastal management and tourism, environmental impact statements and the assessment of environmental impacts. If we do not have those things in relation to coastal management, EISs and the like, we will see a continuation of the practice of large companies, very often multinational companies, picking off one State against another for the lowest standards of environmental protection they can get. Quite clearly, the States are at a serious disadvantage when it comes to protecting the environment properly.

On a Four Corners program the other evening Minister Kelly agreed that it was quite ridiculous that the long-footed potoroo-that was the one example she used-was protected in Victoria but was not protected if it hopped across the border into New South Wales. Of course, the issue of endangered species goes well beyond that: it goes to properly protecting the ecological systems in this country so that the full range of species-animals, plants and, indeed, all other parts of the ecology which support those more obvious species-can also be protected.

That can be done only at the national level through national inventories and national protective laws. It is clear that the full exercise of those Federal powers is capable of controlling well over 90 per cent of those activities that damage those very important elements of our environment.

In the past we have seen coalition governments and the present Hawke Government use those powers. The Fraser Government used its external affairs powers to prevent sand mining on Fraser Island and, through the operation of that power, effectively stopped a damaging operation on an environmentally sensitive island until such time as, more recently, the present Government saw fit to move towards World Heritage status for the island. It is fair to comment that it seems most unlikely, given what we have heard from the Federal Opposition, that in 1991 it would move down the same road and use those powers in the way in which Prime Minister Fraser was prepared to use them.

In the case of the Hawke Government we have seen protection of the south- western region of Tasmania, the Franklin River area. It is interesting to note and to put on record that that was done not only under the exercise of the external affairs powers but also involved the use of section 51(xx) of the corporations' powers under the Constitution. That decision, which was challenged in the High Court and upheld, rested on the use of both powers.

I notice that Minister Richardson is in the chamber and will be speaking shortly on this matter. He will know that section 5 of his own ozone protection legislation drew specifically on the use of the corporations' powers. So far as I am aware, not only has there been no challenge to that provision, but also there has not even been a suggestion that the law may be challenged. We have seen the use of those powers by governments of both major political parties.

What do we have now? We now have every indication of a very considerable backdown by the Federal Government and a deferral to the States of many of those powers. I have with me a copy of discussion draft 4 of the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment. I understand that this is the document to which the Federal Government and the States are now working. We find in paragraph 3.1.2 (iii) under `Commonwealth responsibilities' that the Commonwealth is specifically agreeing to:

consult with and . . . secure the agreement of the States and Territories at First Minister level prior to entering into any international commitments which impose costs or obligations on the States or Territories.

In parenthesis in that paragraph, preceding the phrase about securing agreement, we see the words `use its best endeavours to'. It indicates in my mind that the Federal Government is prepared to not enter into any of those international agreements if a State or Territory does not agree. The words in parenthesis beg the question. What happens if the `best endeavours' fail to secure an agreement? The implication from the rest of the document is fairly clear that in those circumstances the agreement would not be entered into. I draw attention to paragraph 3.1.4 which says:

When ratifying any international agreement on environmental matters, the Commonwealth will include in the instrument of ratification a statement on the manner in which the obligations incurred shall be implemented in Australia. This statement will be consistent with the roles and responsibilities established pursuant to this agreement and may only be made following consultation with the States and Territories at First Minister level . . .

In other words, this is an overriding condition written into this draft agreement between the Commonwealth and the States. Further on, under the heading `Commonwealth Interests: Vertical Cooperation', paragraph 3.3.2 states:
The interests of the Commonwealth in environmental matters are constituted by-
this set of definitions defines what shall be the Commonwealth interest in environmental matters-
(iv) matters where the relevant States or Territories agree that there is a national interest . . .

In other words, if the States and Territories do not agree that a matter is in the national interest, then, by definition under this section, it is not a matter for Commonwealth interest. It continues:
(v) matters which the Commonwealth and a majority of the States agree are matters of national interest . . .

Quite clearly, that states that, if a majority of the States do not agree, the Commonwealth essentially has its hands tied by the intergovernmental agreement on the environment which is under discussion.

The Democrats are vitally concerned that, at a time when there is need for an even more positive, more deliberate and more far-reaching exercise of Commonwealth powers to protect the environment in all those areas I have mentioned, at a time when the Australian public is more environmentally aware than it has been at any time in the history of this country, at a time when the majority of Australians want the Federal Government to move more forcefully and more deliberately in this area-precisely at this time-it seems that the Federal Government is walking away from its responsibilities.

It seems that the Government is prepared to accept the lowest standards from the States in terms of environmental protection and to pass onto the States very considerable costs in relation to the protection of the environment when a State wants to pick up those issues. We call on the Federal Government to reverse its stand and to move strongly to exercise those constitutional powers, which undoubtedly it possesses.
