TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after ``Federal Government to'', substitute ``understand the critical need in Australia for sustainable development subject to appropriate Commonwealth and State environmental safeguards.''.

I have moved that amendment because there is a need for reality in the environmental debate. Regrettably, the Australian Democrats have yet to acknowledge this. This puts at risk Australia's capacity to undertake the sort of environmental protection which can come only from a society with the financial ability to sustain the very real costs of environmental protection.

The best ally of environmental degradation is poverty-just look at Ethiopia. A society which is sufficiently vibrant, healthy and strong has the best prospects of environmental protection; it is able to afford the costs of conservation. Land degradation is the greatest individual cause of environmental breakdown in Australia. Australian farmers are less likely to protect, and less capable of protecting, the land when they are going broke, as they are now, than when they are economically viable. It is a simplistic nonsense to say that there is an inevitable and total conflict between developing and protecting the environment.

Mr Kerin, the Treasurer, put his finger on it very well. I hope that the Government will recognise that my amendment is worthy of its support because Mr Kerin certainly supports this view. When speaking with people who call for negative economic growth as the only path to ecological survival, such as the Australian Democrats, Mr Kerin said:
That is acceptable if you happen to be fabulously wealthy, landed and indifferent to the fate and future of those who are not.

It is not acceptable if you happen to be a subsistence peasant in the Third World, a bonded labourer without access to clean drinking water or fuel, wood or proper housing or health care or clothing, or an unemployed factory hand in the suburbs of Melbourne or Sydney.

And we have quite a few of them at the moment-thanks to the Government's engineered recession. The fact is that there is no inevitable conflict between a growing and healthy economy and preservation of the environment. This nation should be looking at the whole concept of sustainable development.

We wish to amend this urgency motion so that the Federal Government understands the critical need for sustainable development subject to appropriate State and Commonwealth environmental safeguards. There is no doubt that some Government members understand that need. I have just quoted one of them-Mr Kerin.

I admit that we are at some loss to understand the Government's total policy. In the last two days Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has been actively seeking to undermine the Government's policy as outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) of cooperation with the States. What is the Government's policy? Is it, as Mrs Kelly says, crass politics? Will it be sustainable? Is it likely to be changed if Mr Keating becomes the leader? Of course, Mr Keating is being run out of the stable by Senator Richardson. Will Mr Keating be the Green alternative? Is he wearing the Green colours on this track?

It is vital that the Australian people know exactly what the Government's policy will be. Is it the one being undermined by Mrs Kelly or is it the Prime Minister's? Will we see this cooperative, positive development-which certainly the Opposition supports-of relationships between the States and the Commonwealth so that ground rules can be established, and so that we can have sustainable development and an honest, coherent and understandable approach to development which protects the environment? We must have appropriate environmental safeguards-and the only way we can get them is through cooperation with the States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague Senator Michael Baume. I am pleased to see that we have moved this amendment to put some commonsense back into the urgency motion moved by the Australian Democrats. Senator Baume summed it up when he talked about the reality, which is that there are currently over one million people out of work in Australia; that we have balance of payments problems approaching $10m to $20m; and that we have an international debt of $140 billion-and that continues to rise. The Government has been dithering with this sustainable development and its resource legislation. It seems to have lost its leadership and it is certainly not doing the country any good.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember very well before the last election the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, running around the country touting himself as the only option in terms of environmental management. I think that he sucked in the Australian Conservation Foundation. But where are we today? We are still arguing and the country is still divided over these types of issues. Today, we have the Australian Democrats coming out and saying that they want the Federal Government to more widely exercise its constitutional powers.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as a Tasmanian I can tell you of the effect of those powers and their effectiveness in Tasmania. We are virtually a bankrupt State, and have been ever since Senator Gareth Evans sent spy flights to check out what was going on. As a result of the stopping of sensible development in Tasmania, we have a State that is divided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Forestry Commission owes $400m.

—Yes. I am talking about Senator Coulter, who is a conservationist, and his ideas about clean air and all the rest of it. The result of those spy flights and kowtowing to the Green movement in Tasmania is that we have had a fossil fuel burning generator puffing out all the emissions about which Senator Coulter complains every day. It is costing Tasmanian taxpayers and consumers heaps of money, all because we have closed down some of the projects that the Hydro Electric Commission wanted to go ahead with.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure that most people would know that, because of the dithering that has been going on and all the uncertainty, we have lost a very good opportunity in the Wesley Vale mill, which Senator Button was supporting so strongly. That issue has been going on and on; it is like Blue Hills. We have ended up with a position now where any developer that wanted to support APPM in that project would have second thoughts. In fact, Noranda has already made that point quite clear.

When a State or country is falling upon hard times, as Australia and Tasmania are-Tasmania has the highest unemployment rate in the country and our youth unemployment figures are standing at 40 per cent-we have to take a good hard look at our States and the economy and go back to doing the things that we do best. Tasmania has always done best in agriculture, forestry, mining and tourism. Forestry and mining have absolutely had the stuffing kicked out of them because of the uncertainty. They are not just my words. One only has to talk to representatives of the industry. If we look at the mining industry in Tasmania, we can see that Tasmania's mineral production exceeded $1 billion last year for the first time. The industry employs about 20,000 Tasmanians. The Tasmanian Chamber of Mines report states:

Mixed and often negative signals have been sent to industry by this Government on issues such as land use, energy pricing, development rules and environmental regulation. These have combined to make investors feel at best, uncertain or at worst, unwelcome.
The report also states:
Exploration activity has continued its long term decline. This decline in exploration effort will impact directly on the industry's long term ability to sustain itself.

My own State of Tasmania is in such a mess at the moment because of the sorts of Federal controls we have had in the past and the uncertainties that have been caused by the Federal Government choosing to exercise its constitutional powers, for example, when an election is coming up and it needs to support the Green movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The refusal to log forests, the failure to approve pulp mill guidelines, the inability to mine rare earths and other pressing controversies will add to the overall bill for environmental consciousness. The Australian Democrats seem to be incapable of learning that we cannot completely protect or preserve everything.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt, and no-one would argue, about protecting the environment. Certainly, the Democrats do not have any monopoly on the wish and the desire to protect the environment; we all do. Even the ALP does. It makes a vote winning election gimmick out of it but I suspect that deep down a few of its members genuinely want to protect the environment.

The proposal by the Democrats in this motion is not what is needed. We do not need the Commonwealth to more widely exercise its constitutional powers to protect the environment. We need the Government more responsibly to exercise those powers so that we do not have the sorts of decisions that are made in relation to Coronation Hill, where the environment was really a very minor part of the consideration. It was a decision that could have meant so much to Australia's economy, so much to the one million people who are unemployed. There will be more people unemployed because of the irresponsible use by this Government-this Federal Government, this central Government-of its environmental and other powers.

I am amused at some of the things that Senator Coulter talked about. As I understand what he said in his speech, he was criticising the Queensland Government, the Western Australian Government and the Tasmanian Government for looking at coal-fired power stations. Is that what Senator Coulter was doing? I hope I did not get him wrong on that?

TALK.START.PARA: —And Queensland with Tully Millstream.

—And Queensland with the coal-fired power station. I tell Senator Coulter that he is about to become the victim of a very clever trap. There are a lot of people who are now against the Tully Millstream. Does Senator Coulter know why? Because there are enormous amounts of coal in Queensland and they want to use the coal. They do not want to go to Tully Millstream for power because they want to burn all that coal and fix up the ozone layer and whatever else it does. Senator Coulter is a pawn in that. He is being trapped into supporting that by opposing Tully Millstream.

SPEECH.PARA: Tully Millstream is what this country needs to get its power from resources there cheaply, economically and in an environmentally sound manner. The Queensland Electricity Commission has spent millions of dollars doing an environmental impact survey into that. The conservationists are against it. Have any of those conservationists from CAFNEC or the groups in the north Queensland areas ever gone through, ever accepted QEC's offer to look at the scheme, to find out what it is about, to look at the environmental reports and to see that there is no problem with that proposal environmentally?
As far as World Heritage listing goes, there will be more areas given by the QEC into the wet tropics World Heritage area. It is going to increase the area in that particular region.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't understand.

—Senator Coulter can say that we do not understand. He will come back to me, as will Senator Kernot, with the questions: what about wind power? What about solar power? If Senator Coulter can convince me that those projects are economically sustainable, I will be all for them. I agree with wind power; I agree with solar power. But we have to be able to do it economically. Hydro power is as pure and as good to the environment as water is, but it just does not add up.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Coulter to get Senator Kernot to support me in this. When the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure finishes its current inquiry into satellite broadcasting, I will propose-Senator Coulter can ask Senator Kernot to assist me-that the Committee look into wind, solar, gas, methane and coal power. We will have an inquiry to see whether they are economically sustainable. If they are, I am with Senator Coulter. But they are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are prejudging it now, are you?

—Let us have the inquiry. We cannot just dismiss the one million people who are unemployed as a result of this Government's policies. It is also a result of the fact that people like Senator Coulter refuse to have proper development in this country. They refuse it and throw more and more people on the scrap heap for fairytale ideas that come from the bottom of the garden. They do not understand what it does. That is the reason why we must support the amendment. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing both the urgency motion moved by Senator Coulter and the amendment moved by Senator Baume. In doing so, I would like to congratulate Senator Coulter for at least putting the debate over the last few days into proper perspective. The debate ought to be about the substance of the issue. It certainly has not been.

SPEECH.PARA: The urgency motion talks about the Federal Government using its powers more widely so as to more effectively and comprehensively protect the Australian environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be more wisely, not more widely.

—I think that, in terms of the breadth of division of the last few years and in its substance, the national Government has used its powers very widely and, I would like to say, very wisely. It may be good enough for Senator Macdonald to allege that no-one in the Labor Party might care and that it was all done as some sort of stunt but, whatever else the Labor Party has or has not done in the course of the last few years, I shall look back with great pride at a number of environmental decisions, particularly in relation to the wet tropics and Tasmania. Those decisions were taken by the Commonwealth despite the objection of the States.
—Where will you find the wet tropics in Tasmania?

—I said `the wet tropics and Tasmania'. Senator Macdonald did not hear me properly. While I was still the relevant Minister and there was no Federal-State process, on a number of occasions in the Senate I made it clear-and I am sure that Senator Coulter will recall this-that in the future the Commonwealth would much prefer, for example in World Heritage nominations, to have the agreement of the States. That made simply good sense. In December 1988, I attended in Brazil a meeting of the World Heritage Committee and witnessed the spectacle of State Ministers running through delegates, putting a different view to the Commonwealth and, in fact, attempting to gravely distort the debate. While that could be overcome in terms of a decision being taken, it was certainly over time going to bring Australia's position into some disrepute.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, that was not sustainable-to use a word that has arisen quite a few times during this debate. I made it clear then that from now on this Government would attempt to get the agreement of the States. For the next nomination that was then proposed, which related to Shark Bay in Western Australia, that process began while I was the relevant Minister and continued until the position was reached where the Government could finally get the Western Australian Government to agree. The point is that what is happening now in this process with the States is no real change from what I said before. It does not mean that the Commonwealth will walk away from the exercise of its power when that is necessary, even if that is to override a State.

I shall go through a number of points. Firstly, Senator Coulter is relying on a document that was prepared in April largely by State officials. That fourth draft was prepared on the basis that the States and the Commonwealth would go away to discuss it, which is what occurred, and that they would reconvene in August to go over that draft. In the interim, the Commonwealth very substantially redrafted that fourth draft and did not accept much of what it contained because in far too big a way it represented a diminution of the Commonwealth's role, responsibility and power. Therefore, the Commonwealth changed the whole structure of that document. I think that honourable senators will find that the States have pretty well accepted the contents of that redraft. I do not believe that they will find too much to concern themselves about in the final draft when it appears. Obviously, today I cannot say what the final draft will contain, because it is still a matter for negotiation.

Inherent in Mrs Kelly's approach to these negotiations with the States has been the view that we had to have proper national standards. Senator Coulter used the phrase, `lowest common denominator', suggesting that in some way any one State with an unacceptable view of the environment would be able to exercise some sort of veto power. Even though I do not think he expressed it in those words, I do not think that is an unreasonable interpretation of what he said.

If that is to suggest that a State with a particularly poor environmental record such as New South Wales would be able to veto a Commonwealth decision, that is simply not right. Mrs Kelly has been at pains to point out that the Commonwealth will be looking towards majority decisions and not allowing one or two States to say, `We won't cop this; therefore, the process is not on'. There has to be a real agreement and it will not be, cannot be, a lowest common denominator driven agreement.

On how those things are to be addressed, in all of these intergovernmental negotiations the Commonwealth is going through a very wide range of issues in looking for those national standards. I can quote air quality, water quality, noise, contaminated sites, hazardous wastes, motor vehicle emissions-to use a point which Senator Coulter stressed during his contribution-and waste minimisation; and the ecologically sustainable development groups are looking at the greenhouse issues to which Senator Coulter referred.

I note, of course, that in the amendment moved by Senator Michael Baume there is no reference to ecologically sustainable development, just sustainable development. All honourable senators know what that means when it comes from the Opposition. When the Opposition talks about sustainable development, it talks merely about the capacity of either the timber industry or the mining industry to have unfettered access to any area it likes. That has always been the Opposition's position and will remain so. It is not the Government's position, nor is the Government moving towards it during these negotiations.

Both the Prime Minister and the Minister have made it clear that the Government is prepared to use its constitutional powers to protect the environment, and that will not stop. We will not resile from that position in the course of these negotiations with the States. In relation to resource security, which has obviously been a real point of contention with the environment movement, no approval will be given until the Commonwealth is satisfied with environmental standards. We will also continue to use our powers up-front where necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will accept your addendum to our motion to make it `ecologically' if you like. Would you like that?

—I would like the Opposition to start using the term `ecologically sustainable development'. I would be happy to grant Senator Baume leave to change his amendment to that effect, because that would be a sign that the Opposition is beginning to understand. But I will get to the reasons why I oppose the amendment in any event in a moment.
—I see. That was just a debating point.
—No, it is not a debating point; it is a very substantive point. However, there is another substantive point which overrides it.
—In that case, if it would encourage you to support the amendment, we will add it in happily.

—I would like the Opposition to add it in because, as I said, the Opposition has never talked about `ecologically sustainable development'. The Opposition's amendment uses the word `understand'-the need for the Government to understand the importance of it. It is the Labor Party which brought up the need for that sort of development in this country, which put it on the agenda for political debate and which began all of those groups discussing it. We are the ones who kicked off a debate on that sort of development in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So we do not need to understand it; we always did. If the Opposition were to amend its motion to read `the need for the Opposition to understand it' we would be very happy to support it, as would the Democrats. It would go through here unanimously and we would be delighted. I can give the Opposition the further undertaking that it will get leave to do that if it seeks to do it. However, I suspect it will be a long and unhappy wait for most of us if we seek to wait for the Opposition to wake up on any of those points.

It was in some of the speeches of Opposition senators that the game, to some extent, was given away. We had Senator Macdonald's obsession with Tully-Millstream. That was quite an issue way back even in 1988, but certainly by 1989 it was a big issue in Queensland.
As the Minister, I did go up to inspect the Queensland Electricity Commission's plans for the protection of two species. I do not recall their names.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you support the project, don't you?

—Just hang on, Senator Macdonald. I said that the Commonwealth would support the project's going ahead but with a very big proviso that the need for the power was demonstrated. There has been an examination of this. But I do not believe that the Commonwealth is yet in possession of anything like the information that would be required for it to come to the conclusion that there had been a demonstration of the need for this power.
—So there are no environmental problems with it?

—It is ridiculous to say that there are no environmental problems with a very big hydro-electric dam which must inundate a World Heritage area. That makes it a big problem. But if there is a demonstrated need for power, the World Heritage Convention itself allows for acts of that kind.

SPEECH.PARA: So there is an environmental problem which does not go away. As someone who has been there and looked at what the Queensland Electricity Commission has been intent upon doing, I would have to say that it has made a very real attempt in respect of those two species and I commend it for its efforts. Having commended the Commission, it does not mean, however, that we support the project. So far as the Commonwealth is concerned, that will depend entirely on a proper examination of the need for the power.

We must all remember that the need for extra power will diminish in Australia over the course of the next decade. There will be in place in this country a number of savings in the area of energy which will transform the way in which we, as a nation, think about energy issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would save a lot of money and provide employment too.

—It will provide a lot of employment and the prospects for savings are massive. That is why that Tasman Institute report of a week or two ago is so much nonsense. That is something else that we have to debate in the chamber at another time. I was particularly annoyed by it.
—You are on.

—Good. I hope we can. In the last couple of moments left to me, I turn to some of the points raised by the Opposition. First, Senator Michael Baume said to us that there was a need for reality in the environment debate. If there was, we would not be looking to Senator Baume or the Opposition to give us any of it. Over the last four or five years the Opposition has demonstrated that it has a complete inability ever to come to grips with what the environmental debate is about. I think Senator Calvert gave us a very good demonstration of that when he referred to Wesley Vale. Access Economics has taught the Liberal Party to raise at every opportunity the subject of Wesley Vale, as if, in some way, this was a great failing by the Commonwealth in terms of environmental policy.
—It was.

—It just was not. It was a great failing in the first instance by the then Premier, Robin Gray, to come up with a decent set of environmental standards; a huge failure which we were able to overcome in a flash. But we had to deal with a company which was facing an inquiry in Canada. Although Noranda could not afford to agree with the standards that we announced, it could agree later on once much higher standards had been imposed upon it by the Canadian Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition talks about the reasons for the mess in Tasmania. I hope that by now all Tasmanians understand that the reason for the mess in Tasmania was the complete inability by the then Premier, Robin Gray, to come to grips with fiscal policy. He attempted to spend, spend and spend to hide the inadequacies of his Government. Unfortunately, that has caught up with every Tasmanian and every Tasmanian has to bear the burden of those years of profligate waste. Profligate waste is typical of Opposition efforts in this regard.

All we had from Senator Macdonald was again an obsession with one project-we were told about a refusal to log forests, an inability to mine rare earths, et cetera. What that really amounts to is a statement of where the Opposition stands in this debate. Sustainable development to the Opposition means unfettered access to any extractive industry to any part of Australia and that is something we will not wear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That my amendment be amended to read as follows:

Omit all words after ``Federal Government to'', substitute ``confirm the critical need in Australia for ecologically sustainable development subject to appropriate Commonwealth and State environmental safeguards.''.

By way of a very brief explanation, I take the point of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) that it would be difficult for the Government to support an amendment outlining the need for the Government to understand, the inference being that it does not at present understand. Whether that is so is a matter that we could debate.

My interest in this matter is seeing the position confirmed that there is a critical need in Australia for sustainable development, subject to appropriate Commonwealth and State environmental safeguards, which I understand to be the formal position of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Government, and a position which I also understand is being undermined by Mrs Kelly in her private meeting with environmentalists, which is now a matter of public concern. Having met the Government's objections, I now ask that the Government support our amendment, as amended.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Government, I have no difficulty in saying that we can support an amendment that confirms the critical need in Australia for ecologically sustainable development subject to appropriate environmental safeguards. That is fine. The trouble is that in this place we will never agree with the definition of `appropriate'. That is not up for debate. Appropriateness is in the mind of the beholder. As far as the Government is concerned, we can agree with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-We would oppose this because, quite clearly, the wording indicates that the Opposition still does not understand that ecologically sustainable development does not need to be subject to anything. TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 June this year, the Commissioner of Taxation stated that the modern Australian Taxation Office, under self-assessment, aimed to become `an organisation of people equipped, trained and committed to helping taxpayers and their clients carry out their responsibilities under the law'. He went on to state that by becoming such an organisation the Office hoped to maximise voluntary compliance amongst taxpayers. These are notions which I fully support.

SPEECH.PARA: In order to help the Australian Taxation Office become an organisation committed to helping taxpayers to carry out their responsibilities under the law, the Treasury, through its administration of the Office, has as one of its income tax subprograms a taxpayer assistance group. Two of the objectives of this group are to `conduct effective publicity campaigns to educate taxpayers and other clients by communicating changes to tax law and administration to improve the level of voluntary compliance' and to `publish in a timely manner, technical advice and non-technical information to educate taxpayers.' Again, these are concepts and objectives which we all fully endorse.

Today I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate particular aspects of the ATO's publicity campaign. A campaign of fear and certain misinformation is being promoted which is not in line with the stated aims and objectives of the Australian Taxation Office's client assistance group. In fact, it is not in line with everyday normal business practice.

There are a number of aspects which I wish to raise. To begin, I wish to highlight the ATO's handling of the case of the illegal immigrant portrayed in media release No. 20 of 30 April 1991. The release was headed `Heavy Penalties Follow Misuse of Tax File Numbers'. I seek leave to have this press release incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The release read as follows-
The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Trevor Boucher, said that today's decision in a Sydney court indicates that mechanisms are in place to ensure tax file numbers retain their high integrity.

The case involved an illegal immigrant who lodged two tax returns. He used his own name and tax file number on one return but omitted the income he earned in the name of a friend. He also included income he earned on a return lodged in this friend's name.
This meant he understated his income and took advantage of the tax free threshold twice, despite the fact that the threshold is not available to non-residents.

The magistrate found the defendant guilty of 9 charges, including using another person's tax file number, using a false identity in the course of his employment and making a false and misleading statement in a tax return. He was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment and fines totalling $9186. These fines included an order to pay the Commissioner 200% of the tax avoided in addition to the tax payable due to the understated income.
`The heavy penalties handed down in this case show that it is simply not worth trying to misuse tax file numbers for personal gain', said Mr Boucher.
`The new tax file number arrangements were introduced to fight tax evasion. Any anti-evasion procedures will inevitably challenge some people to try and beat the system.
In designing our systems and work practices we have looked at the potential for tax file numbers to be used for improper purposes and have guarded against possible fraud.

We trust our staff who administer the system. Our organisation relies on our people to safeguard the interests of all Australians. To further protect the integrity of the tax file number system, we have built in strict safeguards such as reconciliations, computer access control and quality assurance procedures', added Mr Boucher.
`The introduction of proof of identity measures, strict privacy guidelines and severe penalties for improperly using tax file numbers further secures the system', concluded Mr Boucher.
Canberra
30 April 1991

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan). The Senate may be thinking, `Why bring up a media release from 30 April?'. It is because the media release is still being used as the basis of articles being written about this matter. In the last three weeks a regular article written by a well-known tax expert in Australia has been published in two popular dailies-the Examiner and the Mercury. This particular expert also writes for other mainland papers. However, the press release of 30 April gives, unfortunately, the wrong information. The ATO knows this but has done nothing to correct what has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: The ATO has preferred to have incorrect punitive aspects of not complying with the Income Tax Assessment Act published and disseminated. Consequently, an incorrect aura of fear of what could happen to everyday taxpayers has developed. This press release of 30 April gives the impression that the misuse of the tax file number will result in heavy penalties. There are penalties for the misuse of the tax file number, as there should be, but they are not in accordance with those given in that press release.

Briefly the facts, as per the Tax Office release-I emphasise that they are facts `as per the Tax Office release'-involve an illegal immigrant who lodged two returns. According to the release, he used his own name and tax file number on one return, but omitted the income he earned in the name of a friend. He also included income he earned on a return lodged in his friend's name. This meant that he understated his income and took advantage of the tax-free threshold twice, despite the fact that the threshold is not available to non-residents, which illegal immigrants are.

The release then went on to state that the magistrate found the defendant guilty of nine charges, including using another person's tax file number, using a false identity in the course of his employment and making a false and misleading statement in a tax return. He was sentenced to six months imprisonment and ordered to pay fines totalling $9,186. These fines included an order to pay the Commissioner of Taxation 200 per cent of the tax avoided in addition to the tax payable due to the understated income.
The same press release records Mr Boucher, representing the Australian Taxation Office, saying:
The heavy penalties handed down in this case show that it is simply not worth trying to misuse the tax file numbers for personal gain.

Mr Peter Roach in a recent article, `A Taxing Interpretation', in the August edition of the Charter magazine, expressed amazement that an offence against a relatively new taxation legislation provision could be thought to warrant so great a penalty as imprisonment for a term of six months.

Consequently, the matter was further investigated by Mr Peter Roach who, by the way, is a former senior member of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. He contacted the Australian Taxation Office, which directed him to the officer responsible for the case. According to Mr Peter Roach's article, the information thus obtained should give us all cause for concern.

The sentence for imprisonment referred to in the media release of 30 April 1991 had nothing to do with a tax file number offence or any other taxation offence. The sentence for imprisonment arose out of the wrongdoer's status as an illegal immigrant, an offence or offences for which he had been dealt with at the same time. That explains the reference in the press release to the offender's being an illegal immigrant-something which would seem to have no relationship to the tax offences or their seriousness. But it does not explain why the press release has been expressed in the way in which it has.

Mr Peter Roach, believing that an error had been honestly made and that the Commissioner would correct it once he had been informed of the facts, wrote to the Commissioner. The reply that came to hand was sufficient to cause such concern that it became the base of the article which I am referring to today. This article quotes the Commissioner's reply, and I would like to comment on a number of the statements quoted. Firstly, the Commissioner states:
I agree that the statement of facts contained in the media release . . . could be construed as implying the defendant received a prison sentence for tax offences.

I do not know how else this would be construed. The Tasmanian newspaper articles I referred to at the beginning of my speech were headed `Tax Evaders Beware' and quoted directly the relevant section from the Australian Taxation Office release, which states:

The magistrate found the defendant guilty of 9 charges, including using another person's tax file number, using a false identity in the course of his employment and making a false and misleading statement in a tax return. He was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment and fines totally $9186.

The press release does not imply that it `could be' misconstrued. This is more than semantics. The press release states that because of the misuse of the tax file number, amongst other misdemeanours, the man was imprisoned. There is no question about this. But that is not all. The Tax Commissioner in his letter back to Mr Peter Roach says:

The release was written on the basis of information supplied to our National Office by staff who attended the court hearing. The release was then referred back to staff to check the facts for accuracy before it was issued.
Unfortunately, in this case, this procedure was not sufficient to ensure that the release was unambiguous.

The release was not ambiguous. The Commissioner should have conceded that the press release was wrong and issued a statement to this effect. Rather, the public was left with the impression that misuse of the tax file number could lead to six months imprisonment and a 200 per cent fine. In reply to this accusation, the Commissioner states:
Nevertheless, I do not believe the comments attributed to the Commissioner of Taxation are seriously misleading.
Further, the Commissioner states:
To my knowledge our media release did not receive any significant coverage.

I have already noted that in Tasmania the press release did receive wide coverage and, according to Peter Roach, the information that a prison sentence and misuse of the tax file number are linked has been used by a major publisher here and on the mainland. Therefore, a retraction of the original release is warranted and also necessary. Those who commit tax offences do warrant prosecution and enforcement is necessary. But let us have the correct facts. The punishment deserves to fit the crime.

This is not the only area where the ATO has implied more than is necessary in its press releases or comments. Let us take the auditing of Australia's top 100 companies. Our Tax Commissioner has been quoted as saying that the majority of Australia's top 100 companies have not paid enough tax for a number of years, that the top 100 companies have revealed significant understatements of tax.

When asked by journalists whether this was tantamount to accusing the companies of cheating, this was denied. However, little was made of the fact that the audits revealed no cases of tax avoidance as under part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Most issues covered by the large case audits were technical disputes. The amounts collected by the Tax Office represented grey areas in the law-the same areas which have been in dispute between the Tax Office and large companies for many years because the tax laws have contained a great deal of uncertainty. Before self-assessment, the grey areas in the laws were identified through assessing procedures and ATO inquiries, but now this is the responsibility of the companies and they have to know the law as they, not the ATO, determine their tax liabilities; yet it is the Taxation Office or the Commissioner who determines the interpretation of the law through his rulings and discretions. As a result, a catch 22 situation exists.
The editorial in the Australian of 1 July summarises this situation aptly. It states:

In the case of the top 100 companies, the extent of their crime seems to have been an over-zealous attempt to minimise tax, compounded by the confusion of self assessment according to highly complex tax laws.

Mr Boucher (has) eschewed an air of sanctimoniousness when alleging these abuses, if that is what they are. Self-righteousness will have to wait until there is a genuine attempt to simplify the tax laws, and embody them in a spirit of public service.

However, the overall result in the publicity realm, which concerns me, is that Australia's top 100 companies have been tainted by the ATO as possible cheats. The implication is there, no matter what the Commissioner says. As the article in the Australian of 1 July states, `The taxman's zeal comes at a price'. According to Bob Bryant of the Corporate Tax Association, who was quoted in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, this `vigorous' campaign of auditing `has led to unprecedented hostilities'. According to the article, Mr Bryant said:
Relationships between major companies and the ATO has suffered. These taxpayers are more wary of the commissioner today and are less inclined to take him at his word.

These are unfortunate comments indeed and are worth drawing to the attention of the Senate. Therefore, I am concerned that the Australian Taxation Office has misused its publicity machine. A big brother attitude as a consequence of disseminating and promoting fear based on incorrect facts seems to become part of that pattern. This should not be so. Comments and releases from the Australian Taxation Office should always err on the side of honesty and correctness. A campaign of fear and misinformation should have no part in `its effective publicity campaign to educate taxpayers and other clients'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In relation to all land within the Kakadu National Park (including the area added to the Park by Proclamation dated 21 June 1991): (a) what interests in respect of that land or in respect of any minerals on, in or beneath that land were held (other than by the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth agency), and by whom, immediately before the land was declared to be within the Park; (b) what (i) Commonwealth, and (ii) Northern Territory laws apply to the interests identified in response to (a): and (c) which of the interests identified in response to (a): (i) had expired at some time before 21 June 1991, when did they expire and for what reason, or (ii) are expected to expire at some future time, when will they expire and for what reason in each case, or (iii) are not expected to expire at some specific future time.
(2) On what occasions, and in respect of what interests, has the Minister administering the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act given approval in writing under paragraph 8B(1)(b) of the Act.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Kakadu National Park consists of a number of separate areas of land that have been declared to be part of the Park at different times. The status of the numerous mining and other interests which exist, or which may exist, within the Park is not a simple matter. Their status will depend on whether they were in existence on 1 July 1978 or created subsequently and, what action if any has been taken in respect of a particular interest since that date.

Prior to commencement of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978 on 1 July 1978 the fee simple of all land in the Northern Territory was vested in the Commonwealth. All exploration for minerals and mining was regulated by the Mining Ordinance 1939 and its Regulations (except in the case of prescribed substances within the meaning of the Atomic Energy Act 1953, for which exploration and mining was regulated by the Atomic Energy Act 1953 and Regulations made under it).

On and from 1 July 1978 the fee simple of all land in the Northern Territory became vested in the Northern Territory except such land as the Commonwealth re-acquired pursuant to section 70 of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978. Subsections 70(2) and (3) of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978 enabled the Commonwealth to re-acquire Northern Territory land for a public purpose approved by the Governor-General. By virtue of subsection 70(4) those interests notified in the Gazette prior to the commencement of self-government vested in the Commonwealth immediately after the commencement of section 69 of that Act on 1 July 1978. Among the areas of land that were reacquired by the Commonwealth on 1 July 1978 were those which together now comprise the Park. By reason of the Self Government Act all mining interests that existed in that land on 1 July 1978 continued to be held from the Commonwealth in accordance with the provisions of the Mining Ordinance 1939 and its Regulations as they stood on that date. Those interests were also subject to the Lands Acquisition Act or, where the land was declared to be part of the Park, the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. Similarly, any new mining interests would have to be created under and subject to the Lands Acquisition Act 1955, the Lands Acquisition Act 1989 or the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975.

Therefore, since 1 July 1978 the creation and management of mining or other interests in the land which now comprises Kakadu National Park has been the responsibility of the Commonwealth and not the Northern Territory Government.
The number of interests which do or which may now exist in the Park is large, running into the

hundreds. It is not presently possible to provide an answer to the honourable senator's question in respect of each such interest. They would need to be examined separately to assess whether a particular interest was in existence on 1 July 1978 or created subsequently, whether it has expired or will expire at some future time and, if expired whether the interest has been renewed or extended.

Whatever mining interests may exist in the Park, subsection 10(1A) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 (which commenced on 18 May 1987) does not permit operations for the recovery of minerals to be carried on in the Park.
Should there be a particular interest or interests to which the honourable senator's question relates I would be happy to provide the relevant information.

(2) My colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has informed me that on no occasion has approval been given for renewal of interests pursuant to paragraph 8B(1)(b) of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act.
